Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Manufacture and Characterization of Nanocrystalline/Amorphous Silicon for Particle Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Elementary Particle Physics Program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Accelerator Physics and Physics Instrumentation Program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program in the Division of Materials Research in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, and the NanoManufacturing Program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation in the Directorate for Engineering.

This is an INSPIRE Track 1 Award to the University of Minnesota for the manufacture and characterization of nanocrystalline/amorphous silicon for particle detection. In alignment with INSPIRE program objectives, this is a high risk, multidisciplinary effort including particle physics, R. Rusack, condensed matter physics, J. Kakalios and materials engineering, U. Kortshagen. The program objectives include: the identification, fabrication and testing of at least one suitable amorphous/nanocrystalline Si material with excellent performance characteristics for charge mobility, recombination rate and robustness to radiation damage; the development of processing conditions for these identified material(s) that allow production of a reasonable detector size and thickness on a practical timescale per device; and technology transfer to industry to produce the materials at scale suitable for detector applications.

In the first phase of the program, the group will utilize an existing dual reactor co-deposition system to produce and study a number of amorphous/nanocrystal silicon films to determine the nanocrystal size and density that will optimize mobility and recombination lifetime. Irradiation studies will factor into this optimization. In parallel with these studies, a new, replacement reactor system with a translatable substrate stage will be designed and fabricated. In the final phase and with the new reactor system, the group's objective is to demonstrate a functioning new co-deposition system for mixed phase growth over a reasonable area, from which larger scale industrial processing could be based.

Development of such scalable nano-manufacturing technologies could enable mixed-phase amorphous/nanocrystalline materials to find a broad range of applications. In addition to the development of innovative new particle detector materials and technologies, novel mixed-phase materials might lead to other important applications, for example potential advances in high efficiency photovoltaic devices, non-volatile memories, materials for medical x-ray imaging, thermo-electrics and electroluminescent devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The upgrade to the luminosity of the Large Hadron Collider at CERN will yield radiation levels that can damage crystalline silicon-based detectors, and will require new detector materials or new concepts in detector design. The ideal semiconductor material for particle detector applications would combine the high mobility and long recombination lifetime of crystalline silicon with the radiation hardness, ease of deposition over large areas and relative low-cost of hydrogenated amorphous silicon.  This INSPIRE project explored the synthesis, characterization and manufacturing of composite amorphous/nanocrystalline materials consisting of hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) containing nanocrystalline silicon inclusions, homogeneously embedded within the a-Si:H matrix (a/nc-Si:H). Improvements in the opto-electronic properties of this material may also lead to other technological applications, such as photovoltaics or thermoelectrics. 

Using a unique dual-chamber co-deposition process developed by Kortshagen and Kakalios at the University of Minnesota, we have investigated the previously reported improvements in the charge transport properties of a/nc-Si:H as a function of nanoparticle density and surface treatment, in order to ascertain the conditions that fully optimize the electronic properties of these materials. Nanocrystalline particles are synthesized in an upstream flow-through tube plasma reactor, where the size of the nanoparticles is determined by the plasma power and gas residence time in the reactor. These nanoparticles are then injected into a second capacitively-coupled plasma deposition system in which the surrounding matrix material is grown. One can investigate the variation of the a/nc-Si:H to the density of embedded nanocrystals, as the crystal fraction is sensitive to the substrates position in the deposition chamber relative to the outlet of the nanoparticle injection tube.

 While this reactor geometry is ideally suited for the deposition of mixed-phase silicon films with varying crystal fractions in a single deposition run, it is unsuited for the deposition of large-scale uniform mixed-phase films. Consequently a new reactor geometry was designed, constructed and tested that allows linear deposition in one direction and translation of the substrate. This research is directed at developing new nanomanufacturing techniques that will enable the homogenous incorporation of nanoparticles in the amorphous matrix using a scalable process, capable of synthesizing uniform material over large areas, required by many applications.

Previous studies have found that the dark conductivity of the a/nc-Si:H films can be enhanced by over an order of magnitude by the inclusion of a small density of nanocrystals, corresponding to a crystal fraction of the composite material of only 2 - 4%. This increase in the dark conductivity is due to a modulation doping effect, reflected in a shift the dark conductivity activation energy with nanocrystal content. At much higher inclusion densities, additional disorder introduced into the amorphous matrix leads to a reduction in the dark conductivity. An important open question is whether this improvement in the dark conductivity will persist after the material is exposed to high doses of ionizing radiation.

The structural and electronic properties of a series of such a/nc-Si:H samples were measured, and were then irradiated at the proton beam irradiation facility at Florida State University. In collaboration with Prof. Rachel Yohay at FSU, films were exposed to 17 MeV protons for total doses up to 1015 protons/cm2. While earlier studies by this project of a/nc-Si:H found that proton irradiation at lower doses led to a metastable degradation of the dark conductivity, the higher proton irradiation doses yielded a pronounced enhancement of the dark conductivity, in some cases by two orders of magnitude, that persists even after extended annealing at 200C. There is no change in the dark conductivity activation energy, indicating that this enhancement is not due to an increase in the density of charge carriers in the film. Studies are underway to determine whether the irradiation induces an increase in the crystalline phase in the composite films, which would have the effect of increasing the charge mobility.

A parallel effort involved the formation of polycrystalline silicon thin films (which have longer drift lengths and better electronic characteristics than a-Si:H) using the composite amorphous/nanocrystalline films as the starting material. In this case the advantage of the nanocrystalline gradient is to provide samples with differing average separation between nanocrystal seeds, yielding larger crystallite grains after annealing. Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy was used to monitor the degree of crystallization and morphology as the composite a/nc-Si:H films were isochronally annealed at 650C. The electrical conductivity, thermopower and thermal conductivity of the resulting pc-Si films yielded a higher thermoelectric figure-of-merit (ZT) compared to both amorphous and mixed-phased films. Further research will investigate recipes for improving ZT that include dopants and higher deposition pressures.
